p: With the increase in confirmed cases, acute cardiac injury is not rare. Early COVID-19 case reports suggested that 5 of the first 41 confirmed COVID-19 patients (12%) had acute myocardial injury, characterized by high-sensitivity cardiac troponin I (hs-cTnI) > 28 pg/mL; of these patients, 4 had severe forms of the disease [ 6]. Later, in another clinical cohort of COVID-19, CK and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) were increased in 13% and 76% of patients, respectively [ 7]. Wang et al. analyzed 138 hospital patients and found that 10 (7.2%) had acute cardiac injury. In addition, critically ill patients had significantly higher levels of myocardial markers, such as CK-MB and hs-cTnI, suggesting that severe patients were more susceptible to acute myocardial injury [ 8].
